name: Anna-Alexandra Marhold
skills: ['Public International Law', 'International Law', 'European Union', 'Politics', 'Human Rights', 'European Law', 'Policy', 'International Trade', 'International Relations', 'Political Science', 'Dutch', 'International Human Rights', 'Russian', 'Foreign Policy', 'Policy Analysis', 'International Organizations', 'International Humanitarian Law', 'Diplomacy', 'Public Policy', 'International Development']
summary:
I am Assistant Professor at the Grotius Centre for International Legal Studies at Leiden Law School, the Netherlands and a Visiting Professor at Vermont Law and Graduate School (VT, USA).

My specializations are International Economic Law, World Trade Organization (WTO) and International Trade Law and the interaction with international and European energy law and regulation.

I am particularly interested in the ongoing crisis in international trade law; security interests and other non-strictly trade-related objectives in international trade law; EU Energy Policy and its interaction with WTO obligations; European energy security, energy and environmental regulation in Preferential Trade Agreements (PTAs); the future of the Energy Charter Treaty; the OPEC cartel; law and economics approaches to energy regulation; the sustainable energy transition; access to supplies and natural resources; public goods; regulation of network industries; squaring energy security with sustainable development and consumer protection; regulation of transit of energy; the Energy Community Treaty and European external energy relations, particularly with the European Neighborhood.

Keywords: 

- International Trade and WTO Law, Economics and Policy
- International and European Energy Law
- Law and Economics
- International Investment Law
- Public International Law
- Natural Resources Law
- Environmental Law and Sustainable Development
- WTO, Energy Charter Treaty
- PTAs and Mega-Regionals
- EU External Relations Law and Energy, Energy Community Treaty

summary:
I am a curious and passionate person who believes in the strength of human relations, no matter what. I consider myself a traveller. I do love travelling and discovering new places by walking and carrying a disproportionate and heavy backpack, knowing that for the long day I will be outside. Besides that, even when I am locked in my room, my mind has already reached many other places that I would never imagine. 

This has been strengthened by my previous experiences abroad. Originally from Italy, I spent part of my third academic year studying at KU Leuven in Leuven, Belgium. Leuven was a revelatory experience that showed me that I love international settings, which is to say engaging with people who have different backgrounds and adventures. 

 Upon my graduation at the University of Perugia, Italy, I spent almost two months living in Istanbul, Turkey. There, I was doing a traineeship that allowed me to work with an international group of people. It boosted my empathy, cross-cultural sensitivity and teamworking skills. Not satisfied, I moved to Brussels for another traineeship, at the Umbria Region - Brussels Office, which allowed me to enter into the 'Brussels bubble' and acquired insights of networking, policy-making process, lobby activities. For that reason, I ended up in Maastricht to study European Studies, specialisation in Global Challenges. 

My drivers? Hard willingness, cross-cultural values, dynamism, perseverance and strong beliefs!

summary:
Kocku von Stuckrad is Professor of Religious Studies at the University of Groningen, the Netherlands. He has published extensively on topics related to the cultural history of religion, science, and philosophy in Europe and North America.

Professor von Stuckrad served as President of the International Society for the Study of Religion, Nature, and Culture (ISSRNC) and as President of the Dutch Association for the Study of Religion (NGG). He also was a founding board member of the European Society for the Study of Western Esotericism (ESSWE). He was co-chair of the Critical Theory and Discourses on Religion Group, as well as the Religion in Europe Group, of the American Academy of Religion. In 2011 he was appointed as Honorary Professor of the Study of Religion at Aarhus University, Denmark. From 2013‚Äì2017, he served as the Dean of the Faculty of Theology and Religious Studies, University of Groningen.

Together with Whitney A. Bauman, he is co-founder and co-director of Counterpoint: Navigating Knowledge, a research center and information hub, located at the interface of academic and non-academic knowledge practices and traditions.

name: Gerasimos Tsourapas
position 2: Senior Lecturer (Associate Professor) in Middle East Politics
degree 2: Summer Program in Arabic (Modern Standard & Egyptian Colloquial)
summary:
Gerasimos Tsourapas works on the international relations of the Middle East and the broader Global South, with a particular focus on the politics of migrants, refugees, and diasporas. He has secured research funding in excess of ¬£1.35 million, and is currently the Principal Investigator of a five-year European Research Council Starting Grant project on migration diplomacy. He is a Senior Fellow of the UK Higher Education Academy, and has been elected as the incoming Chair of the Ethnicity, Nationalism, & Migration Studies (ENMISA) Section of the International Studies Association (2023‚Äì25).

Dr Tsourapas is the author of The Politics of Migration in Modern Egypt ‚Äì Strategies for Regime Survival in Autocracies (Cambridge University Press, 2018) and Migration Diplomacy in the Middle East and North Africa ‚Äì Power, Mobility, and the State (Manchester University Press, 2021). He co-edited, with Prof Maria Koinova, a special issue on 'Diasporas and Sending States in World Politics' for International Political Science Review. His work has also appeared in International Studies Quarterly, European Journal of International Relations, International Migration Review, Journal of Ethnic and Migration Studies, and other leading journals.

Dr Tsourapas has received numerous awards. The Politics of Migration in Modern Egypt was awarded the 2020 ENMISA Distinguished Book Award by the International Studies Association and was shortlisted for the British International Studies Association's L.H.M. Ling Outstanding First Book Prize. His work has also been recognised by the American Political Science Association (Best Dissertation on Migration & Citizenship, 2016), the International Studies Association (Martin O. Heisler Award, 2017), and the Middle East Studies Association of North America (Graduate Student Paper Prize, 2015). He also received the inaugural 2021 ENMISA Emerging Scholar Award by the International Studies Association. 

Dr Tsourapas served as a Fellow at the Center for European Studies, Harvard University (2019‚Äì20) and The American University in Cairo (2013‚Äì14). He received a BA in Economics and Political Science from Yale University (2006), an MSc in International Political Economy from the London School of Economics and Political Science (2007), and a PhD in Politics from SOAS, University of London (2016).

summary:
I guess I always saw myself as a storyteller.  That's why, when I was a kid, I memorised bits from the movies, books and comedians I admired until I was ready to make up my own. It's also why I got degrees in media and literature and ended up working in journalism before I found myself in a great place for anyone who likes telling stories. 

As a teacher, I get to tell stories about culture and communication to international students, and I get to create and carry out communication courses that help them to tell their own stories.

As a Public Relations professional, I try to tell the story of European Studies to anyone who will listen, in person, online and in print, because I'm proud to be a part of a unique international and interdisciplinary programme that prepares young Europeans for a wide range of careers while giving them knowledge and skills that will enable them to adapt to a changing labour market. 

Like a lot of storytellers, I can't sit still for very long, so I'm always on the lookout for opportunities, so if you need someone to help you tell your story, all you have to do is ask.

name: Dimitris Bouris
field of studies 1: The European Union's role in the Palestinian state-building after the Oslo Accords
skills: ['International Relations', 'European politics', 'Politics', 'Middle East', 'Conflict Resolution', 'Euro-Mediterranean Relations', 'State-building', 'Security Sector Refom', 'Judiciary Sector Reform', 'Human Rights', 'EU', 'Political Science', 'Diplomacy', 'Foreign Policy', 'Research', 'French', 'Policy Analysis', 'European Affairs', 'Foreign Affairs', 'European Union']
summary:
Dr Dimitris Bouris is a Senior Lecturer at the Department of Political Science at the University of Amsterdam and a Jean Monnet Chair "The EU as a Global Actor" (ATHENA). He is an Associate Editor of the academic journal European Security and a Visiting Professor at the College of Europe (Natolin). He is also the leader and coordinator of the EU-Middle East Jean Monnet Network EUMENIA (www.eumenia.eu). Dr Bouris is a co-leader of the Europe in the World theme of the Amsterdam Centre for European Studies (ACES), an Academic Board member of the Amsterdam Centre for Middle Eastern Studies (ACMES), an Academic Council Member of the European Neighbourhood Council and a non-resident fellow at the Hellenic Foundation for European and Foreign Policy ELIAMEP. 

His research focus lies at the intersection of International Relations (IR theory, peacebuilding, state-building, security sector reform, conflict resolution), EU Studies (EU External Relations, EU Common Security and Defence Policy) and Middle East and North Africa Studies. Dr Bouris is the author of ‚ÄúThe European Union and Occupied Palestinian Territories: State-building without a State‚Äù (Routledge, 2014). Dimitris is also the co-editor (with Tobias Schumacher) of the ‚ÄúRevised European Neighbourhood Policy: Continuity and Change in EU Foreign Policy‚Äù (Palgrave Macmillan, 2017) and the co-editor (with Daniela Huber and Michelle Pace) of the ‚ÄúRoutledge Handbook of EU-Middle East Relations‚Äù (Routledge, 2022). He has also edited special issues and published a number of scholarly articles in leading peer-reviewed academic journals such as European Security, the Hague Journal on the rule of law, Mediterranean Politics, Global Affairs, International Spectator, the British Journal of Politics and International Relations, International Political Sociology and Geopolitics. He is also a frequent media commentator an has published a number of policy briefs and op-eds for major European and Middle East news and policy outlets such as EUROMESCO, Al Jazeera, Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and Open Democracy.

summary:
The American writer and anthropologist Zora Neale Hurston once said ‚Äúresearch is formalized curiosity. It is poking and prying with a purpose‚Äù. It is this same curiosity that characterizes me and my work.
Ever since I was little, I have been driven by an endless curiosity for knowledge, especially with regards to international affairs and Eastern European affairs, and I strongly believe that research, whether in an academic or professional capacity, is an continuous opportunity for personal and intellectual development. 

Working in an international think tank environment and having worked on projects in Hungary, Kyrgyzstan, China and South Africa, I am comfortable applying my analytical capabilities in a fast-paced work environment and to accomodate to changing circumstances.

Challenging myself every day, and pushing my personal boundaries, I aim to connect with people that share my passion for (East-) European Affairs and make a valuable contribution to the work of my employer.

summary:
Hi! I am a recent graduate of the BA in International Relations with History from Manchester Metropolitan University and am currently studying for an MA in European Studies specialising in Global Policy and Governance Challenges at Maastricht University. I am Spanish and German and have had the opportunity to study in England and Canada, as well as do an internship in Mexico. These opportunities have helped me to open my mind, to discover new cultures and to acquire an international mindset.

I have always tried to go beyond doing what I am supposed to do, so I have worked in different roles at my university, such as student ambassador or mentor, instead of just studying. This has allowed me to expand my practical knowledge and not just my academic knowledge. I have also always enjoyed sports, especially basketball, as I am a team player. My parents have instilled in me since I was a child that change is good and to be a proactive person, that's why I love travelling and getting to know other cultures in depth.

I am looking for an opportunity that takes you beyond a traditional office job and that will allow me to develop a variety of tasks and challenge myself.

summary: For over twenty years I explored, studied, taught and theorized on policy making of the EU in the academic world, both in education and in research. In 2020 I changed my course and went into the everyday business of local public administration. As an expert in European affairs, I advise and assist local administrations, organizations, departments, people in connecting their local values, ambitions and projects with the European arena. As such I make cross-border and cross-departmental connections between ideas, ambitions, good practices and innovative projects from a forward-looking and integrated perspective. The aim is to translate these connections into portfolios, programmes, projects and policies that deliver tangible results for citizens and local business.

name: Gertjan Hoetjes
skills: ['Research', 'Conferences', 'Analysis', 'Politics', 'Political Economy', 'European politics', 'European Affairs', 'Middle East', 'Budgeting', 'Telephone Skills', 'Reception', 'International Economics', 'Publications', 'Dutch', 'Government', 'Writing', 'International Relations', 'English', 'Journalism', 'Event Management']
summary:
Currently I am a lecturer in European Studies at the University of Amsterdam. In this position I am jointly convening several courses revolving around EU Enlargement and External Relations, European Geopolitics, European Integration and Skills Seminar Brussels. In addition, I have taught seminars for the course Middle East: History, Politics and Economy and am a MA thesis supervisor. I have several years of experience as a module convenor of a variety of courses in both the United Kingdom (Durham University) and the Netherlands (University of Groningen). In these courses I have covered several subjects such as politics, political economy, state-society relations and international relations in the Middle East as well as supervising Bachelor and Master Students in Middle Eastern Studies (University of Groningen) and Politics (Durham University). Throughout these years I have distinguished myself as a lecturer by implementing active learning methods in my courses, which has resulted in excellent student reviews about the quality of my teaching. 

As a scholar my research revolves around state-society relations, political economy and international relations in the Gulf region. I obtained my doctoral degree in Middle Eastern Politics at the University in Exeter in March 2020 (after passing the Viva without corrections) with a thesis on the the impact of Internet technology on the Gulf monarchies focusing on Kuwait and Oman. I have presented my work at various conferences and had a number of publications in the International Spectator, edited volumes, Gulf Insight, the HH Sheikh Nasser Mohammad al-Sabah Publication Series and ZemZem. Alongside this,  I have frequently contributed to Gulf State News providing political analysis on Kuwait and have initiated several extra-cirricular activies including being co-organiser of the Gulf Conference 2016 (University of Exeter) and co-founding the Social Movement Theory Reading Group at the University of Exeter.

summary:
I received a bachelor‚Äôs degree in law with honors from the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki in 2012 and two master‚Äôs degrees in European Law (University of Athens - 2013) and in European tax law (Leiden University - 2015). 

On 3 June 2021, I defended my doctoral thesis entitled "Taxation of cross-border inheritances and donations. Suggestions for improvement" at Leiden University after 5 years of research. 

I am working as a tax lawyer with PwC NL's Tax Knowledge Centre and as an assistant professor/academic coordinator at the University of Amsterdam with European and international tax law as main fields of expertise.  

Finally, I monitor and report on Greek tax legislation at the IBFD.
